body: Actually, another detail that may (or may not) be important: the utility method `doCommonStuff()` is actually in a superclass.

Just to clarify... it was a custom provider, but it was a StringAssert not a custom assert. 

I think the key point is it being thrown in a subclass of the test class. I'll try and come b up with a concrete test case for it.

Interestingly, I had a bit of a look at this today, and I can see that the test case for `AssertJMultipleFailuresError` is not expecting any stack traces in the individual failure messages:

https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/d20f3d381960a5ad504e7be9c44e16464cd64b51/src/test/java/org/assertj/core/error/AssertJMultipleFailuresError_getMessage_Test.java#L53-L109

Can you point me in the right direction here @joel-costigliola ? Is this by design? I thought I had seen the stack trace errors (or at least the first line) in the past. Maybe that was back when it was using the plain OpenTest4J `MultipleFailuresError`?

I remember now that we did not include the stack traces for the sake of brevity but that's the same behaviour as opentest4j `MultipleFailuresError` as far as I can see.

What we could do is add a detailed part after the current message and display all failures with their stack traces, it's going to be quite verbose.

Thoughts?

I must be going insane (some might argue that this is not a recent development...).

Actually, we don't need the full stack trace - the top few lines (after AssertJ has removed its contribution) for each failure would be fine. That would do the job but without making it too verbose. (As noted, i thought i saw oit doing this in the past but i must have been mistaken. )

I have another more radical idea i might try though...
We can add the top filtered lines, like 5 per failure?

The top 5 lines might even be too much. I was thinking top 2 or 3.

Ideally, it would be able to find the stack trace line that identifies the entry into the top-level test method, and ignore everything after that. That way it could automatically adapt to the pattern I use of utility assertion methods (which occasionally go through a few layers of indirection) but not include more than is necessary. But I'm not sure how feasible this is.

finding the top level test method is going to be brittle as it depends on the test name itself (can't really infer that) and possibly the test engine. 
let's keep it simple to 3 stack trace elements for now.
not yet, it has fallen under our radar I'm afraid, I'll schedule it for the next release.

issue.title: `satisfies()` with nested assertions obscures stack trace

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

body:
playing with a possible implementation displaying 5 stack trace elements, given this test

```java
@Test
void test4() {
  setRemoveAssertJRelatedElementsFromStackTrace(true);
  then(list("aaa")).singleElement()
                   .satisfies(value -> then(value).startsWith("b"),  // line 38
                              value -> then(value).endsWith("z")); // line 39
}
```

the error message reports the proper line for the failing assertions:
```
[List check single element] (2 failures)
-- failure 1 --
Expecting actual:
  "aaa"
to start with:
  "b"
at MyTest.lambda$2(MyTest.java:38)
-- failure 2 --
Expecting actual:
  "aaa"
to end with:
  "z"
at MyTest.lambda$3(MyTest.java:39)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:78)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
	at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstanceWithCaller(Constructor.java:499)
	at starwars.test.MyTest.test4(MyTest.java:38)
```
